fields.Title of Presentation: Purification of ArtAB, an AB5-type Salmonella Typhimurium DT104 toxin, with single residue mutations for investigation of the enzymatic activity of the A subunit
fields.Description/Abstract:
ArtAB, an AB5-type toxin produced by Salmonella Typhimurium DT104, is composed of a
pentameric receptor-binding (ArtB) subunit and an enzymatically active (ArtA) subunit. ArtA
shares genetic and structural homology with well-characterized AB5-type toxins such as cholera
toxin (CT) and pertussis toxin (PT), but a thorough comparison of the toxins has not been made.
All three of these toxins perform ADP-ribosylation but their cellular targets appear to differ. In
order to assess the enzymatic activity of ArtA, we designed and produced ArtA mutants with
single amino acid mutations at three different residues within the suspected binding pocket of the
enzyme. Mutations were made based on genetic sequence alignments to CT and PT, both of
which have tertiary and quaternary structures that have been solved. The mutations are expected
to abolish the ADP-ribosylating activity of the toxin. Mutant plasmids were successfully
transformed into CleanColi and purified, assembled with ArtB as holotoxin, using D-galactose
agarose affinity chromatography. Purified protein size, presence of subunits, and concentrations
were confirmed with SDS-PAGE and BCA assays. The purified mutant proteins will support an
examination of the binding pocket of ArtA and a comparison of ArtA, CT, and PT, using ADP-
ribosylation assays, PKA and PKC signaling assays, and cellular morphology, proliferation, and
barrier function assays. Understanding the relationship of these three toxins will improve our
understanding of the AB5 toxins, a family that has been demonstrated to contribute to Vibrio
cholerae (cholera) and Bordatella pertussis (pertussis, or whooping cough) virulence and
pathogenicity, but have also shown promise with use as vaccines or vaccine adjuvants.
